Text: Trump‚Äôs now saying saying AOC +3 are anti-Israel. Just fyi, his pet name for Kusher was ‚ÄòThe Jew‚Äô at ‚ÄòCelebrity Apprentice‚Äô not a joke fyi. @realDonaldTrump
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet uses a derogatory term referring to Kushner as "The Jew," which is directed at a Jewish individual. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, as it involves targeting Jewish individuals with dehumanizing language, fitting into the category of rhetorical manifestations aimed at Jewish individuals or their property, community institutions, or religious facilities. The mention of AOC +3 being anti-Israel adds context about Israel but doesn't negate the antisemitic nature of the derogatory term used against Kushner.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet discusses political criticism and a personal nickname without exhibiting discrimination or hostility against Jews. It mentions Trump's reference to Kushner as "The Jew," which is a factual statement about a nickname rather than an expression of antisemitic tropes. The focus is on political criticism, not on stereotyping or racializing Jews. Therefore, it does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by JDA.

Text: In last 7 days (Lockdown-2) India surpassed countries like South Korea, Japan, Israel, Saudi Arabia, Austria, Sweden, Ireland etc in total #Covid19 cases. Many of these countries were worst affected at one point of time.\n\nIn fact, our cases are almost double of South Korea now!
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet compares India's COVID-19 cases to those of other countries, including Israel. It does not contain any statements that target Jewish people or make harmful stereotypes about them. While it mentions Israel, the comparison is about public health data and does not involve antisemitic content as defined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet compares India's COVID-19 cases to those of other countries, including South Korea. It highlights that India has surpassed some nations in case numbers, which is a factual observation based on public health data. The comparison does not involve any antisemitic language or references to Jewish people or Israel, nor does it imply any negative stereotypes about Jews or link them to conspiratorial actions. Therefore, the tweet does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by the JDA.

IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references the security of British Jews in a context that frames any critique as antisemitic. It uses the mention of Jewish security to imply that criticizing this focus equates to antisemitism, thus targeting Jewish individuals or community by association with negative stereotypes and manipulative language. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes manipulation through rhetoric to incite hatred towards Jews.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet in question does not exhibit antisemitic characteristics as defined by the JDA. It discusses a neutral stance supporting coexistence between Israel and Palestine and references the security of British Jews, which is a legitimate concern rather than an expression of prejudice or hostility towards Jews. The content involves policy debate without using stereotypes or promoting hatred, thus it does not qualify as antisemitic under the provided guidelines.

Text: @Conflicts @tvnet Isaiah 17:1-3....Wow who would have thought that it would be the Turkey instead of Israel!

Therefore, it does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by JDA.

Text: "hateful obsession w/Israel often descends into hatred of Jews..Anti-Israel activity on..college campuses led to verbal&physical assaults on Jewish students&we must be honest with ourselves..happening in our space,in the heart of intellectual liberalism." https://t.co/eGswLrcdwK
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet links anti-Israel activity on college campuses to verbal and physical assaults on Jewish students. This connection suggests that opposition to Israel is associated with antisemitic behavior targeting Jewish individuals. According to the IHRA definition, antisemitism can involve blaming Jews for societal issues or accusing them of disloyalty, as it does here by implying Jewish students' loyalty to Israel over their own country. Thus, the tweet reflects antisemitic undertones by associating criticism of Israel with hatred towards Jews, aligning with the IHRA criteria.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet connects anti-Israel activity on college campuses with verbal and physical assaults on Jewish students. According to the JDA, this association can lead to the stigmatization of Jews as a result of their Jewish identity, which violates antisemitism guidelines (B.7 and B.10). It directly links opposition to Israel with hatred towards Jewish individuals, crossing into discriminatory behavior against Jews.

Text: Why was an IRANIAN General who epitomized Iran's call for ‚Äúdeath to America‚Äù and ‚Äúdeath to Israel‚Äù landing in Baghdad hours after an Iranian attack on the US Embassy? ü§îTaking out the terrorist Soleimani was an act of self-defense and stopped him from leading a second attack.

Text: As NYC Turns on Jews, @ewarren Boasts New Endorsement from Anti-Israel Comedian https://t.co/w8nEhGwplk

This linking can be seen as coded antisemitism, thus making the tweet violate the JDA guidelines.
